clean_content:
Definition / general

* Benign cyst of odontogenic origin, characterized by an ameloblastoma-like epithelial lining containing ghost cells that may calcify* Originally described by Gorlin and colleagues in 1962 as a possible oral analogue to pilomatrixoma of skin, owing to the presence of ghost cell keratinization in both lesions

Essential features

* Calcifying odontogenic cysts are located most commonly in the anterior regions of jaws* Microscopically calcifying odontogenic cysts contain an ameloblastoma-like epithelial lining containing ghost cells that may calcify* Calcifying odontogenic cysts are associated with β catenin (*CTNNB1*) mutations

Terminology

* Calcifying odontogenic cyst (COC) is the preferred terminology in the 2017 WHO classification* Nomenclature has been continuously changing, due to debate as to whether COC is a neoplasm or a developmental cyst
    + In 1992, WHO classified this lesion as an odontogenic tumor but continued to use the term calcifying odontogenic cyst+ In 2005, WHO redesignated the lesion as calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor (CCOT)+ In 2017, the term calcifying odontogenic cyst was reapplied to this lesion and it was reclassified as a benign odontogenic cyst* Other archaic names include Gorlin cyst and keratinizing and calcifying odontogenic cyst* Given the diversity of the histopathologic features seen in COC and its tendency to coexist with other odontogenic lesions, complex classification systems have been proposed ([Am J Surg Pathol 2003;27:372](12604894), [J Oral Pathol Med 2008;37:302](18221328), [Reichart: Odontogenic Tumors and Allied Lesions, Illustrated Edition, 2004](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1850970599/pathologyoutl-20))* COC belongs to odontogenic ghost cell family of lesions ([J Oral Pathol Med 2008;37:302](18221328))
          + From a practical standpoint, a spectrum of histopathologic patterns exists, ranging from a benign lesion that is primarily cystic, a benign lesion with a solid pattern of growth to a rare tumor with features of carcinoma
            - Solid lesions are designated [dentinogenic ghost cell tumors](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxilladentinogenicghost.html) in the 2017 WHO classification- Malignant counterpart is [ghost cell odontogenic carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaghostcellodontogeniccarcinoma.html)

ICD coding

* ICD-O: [9301/0](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf?sequence=1#page=89) - calcifying odontogenic cyst* ICD-10: [D16.4](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D16-/D16.4) - benign neoplasm of bones of skull and face* ICD-10: [D16.5](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/C00-D49/D10-D36/D16-/D16.5) - benign neoplasm of lower jaw bone

Epidemiology

* 0.3% of odontogenic cysts ([J Oral Pathol Med 2006;35:500](16918602))* Mean age: 31 years (standard deviation: 21 years) range 5 - 92 years; however, this varies geographically ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:721](29738629))* No consistent gender predominance* Around 33% of cases are associated with odontogenic lesions, most commonly odontoma; odontoma associated COC occurs in younger patients on average (20.4 years) ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:721](29738629))

Sites

* Vast majority of lesions are central COC (within bone of jaw, intraosseous) ([Reichart: Odontogenic Tumors and Allied Lesions, Illustrated Edition, 2004](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1850970599/pathologyoutl-20))* Less commonly, peripheral lesions may be seen (located on gingival tissues, extraosseous) most of which can be classified as [dentinogenic ghost cell tumors](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxilladentinogenicghost.html)* Usually anterior regions of jaws, incisor / cuspid region* Lesions associated with odontoma are most commonly found in the anterior maxilla ([J Oral Pathol Med 2008;37:302](18221328))

Pathophysiology

* Cystic neoplasms with β catenin (*CTNNB1*) mutations in the Wnt signaling pathway
  + In one series, 91% (10/11) cases of CCOT / COC demonstrated *CTNNB1* point mutations COC ([PLoS One 2017;12:e0180224](28658279))+ Immunohistochemistry for LEF1 (a transcription factor of the Wnt pathway) is reported to be positive in 64% (7/11) of CCOT ([Hum Pathol 2015;46:255](25497834))

Clinical features

* Either asymptomatic (incidental radiographic finding) or a painless swelling* Extraosseous lesions present as a gingival swelling, which may be painful* May be associated with other odontogenic pathology, most commonly odontoma ([J Oral Pathol Med 2018;47:721](29738629))

Diagnosis

* Diagnosis can be made on an incisional biopsy or enucleation specimen

Radiology description

* Usually unilocular, well defined radiolucency with focal opacification but may rarely be multilocular ([Br J Radiol 2012;85:548](21828147))* Scattered radiopacities in 33 - 50%* 33% associated with impacted tooth* Usually 2 - 4 cm* Adjacent tooth root displacement, resorption or root divergence may occur ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2006;101:356](16504870))

Radiology images

Contributed by Elizabeth Ann Bilodeau, D.M.D., M.D., M.S.Ed.  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau01a.png)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau01a.png)

Coronal CT

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau01b.png)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau01b.png)

Sagittal CT

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau01c.png)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau01c.png)

Axial CT

Prognostic factors

* Prognosis excellent, few recurrences (< 5% documented)* Rarely, malignant transformation has been reported ([Case Rep Pathol 2013;2013:853095](23956907), [Korean J Pathol 2012;46:478](23136575), [Ann Diagn Pathol 2009;13:394](19917476))

Case reports

* 15 year old Japanese boy with pigmented calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor associated with compound odontoma
  ([Head Face Med 2007;3:35](17892598))* 23 year old man with ameloblastic fibro-odontoma arising from a calcifying odontogenic cyst
    ([Bull Tokyo Dent Coll 2001;42:51](11484795))* 24 year old woman with calcifying odontogenic cyst associated with an orthokeratinized odontogenic cyst ([Head Neck Pathol 2008;2:324](20614303))* 36 year old man with a 5.9 cm calcifying odontogenic cyst treated with 2 stage decompression ([J Oral Maxillofac Surg 2017;75:1915](28390759))* Hybrid odontogenic tumor with features of ameloblastic fibro-odontoma, calcifying odontogenic cyst and adenomatoid odontogenic tumor ([J Oral Maxillofac Surg 2010;68:470](20116726))

Treatment

* Treated by enucleation and curettage* For combined lesions, treat according to characteristics of more aggressive lesion* Large cysts may be decompressed prior to surgical management in a 2 stage approach ([J Oral Maxillofac Surg 2017;75:1915](28390759))

Gross description

* Unicystic, often 2 cm or less; no solid areas* Grossly cystic with focal luminal thickenings

Gross images

Contributed by Elizabeth Ann Bilodeau, D.M.D., M.D., M.S.Ed.  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau04.jpg)

Opened and sectioned cyst

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Cyst lining is of odontogenic epithelium with a well defined layer of palisading basal cells, loosely arranged suprabasal epithelial cells resembling stellate reticulum, similar to ameloblastoma ([microscopic image #1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html#mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenicmicro))
  + Unlike ameloblastoma, variable numbers of cells undergo ghost cell change in suprabasilar epithelium ([microscopic image #1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html#mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenicmicro))+ Pale, eosinophilic ghost cells are altered epithelial cells with preservation of basic cell outline and eosinophilic cytoplasm but loss of the nucleus; ghost cell change may be due to coagulative necrosis, accumulation of enamel protein, aberrant keratinization of odontogenic epithelium and these cells may calcify ([microscopic images #2 - 3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html#mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenicmicro))+ Other variable findings may include:
        - Foreign body giant cell reaction- Proliferation of odontogenic epithelium into the cyst wall which can resemble strands of dental lamina ([microscopic image #4](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html#mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenicmicro))- Dystrophic calcifications- Dentinoid may be laid down next to basal cells:
                * Paucicellular, eosinophilic calcified material considered to represent dysplastic dentin ([microscopic image #4](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html#mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenicmicro))* May be present adjacent to epithelial component* Most likely formed due to an inductive effect of odontogenic epithelium on adjacent mesenchymal tissue* Cyst wall consists of mature fibrous connective tissue containing scattered inflammatory cells (unless secondarily infected)* Reference: [Reichart: Odontogenic Tumors and Allied Lesions, Illustrated Edition, 2004](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1850970599/pathologyoutl-20)

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Elizabeth Ann Bilodeau, D.M.D., M.D., M.S.Ed. and Keith D. Hunter, B.D.S., Ph.D.  

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Hunter05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Hunter05.jpg)
 
[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Hunter06.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Hunter06.jpg)

Ameloblastomatous lining & ghost cells

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau07.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau07.jpg)

Calcification of ghost cells

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Hunter08.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Hunter08.jpg)

Island of epithelium with ghost cells

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau09.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau09.jpg)

β catenin

[![Missing Image](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau10.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic_Bilodeau10.jpg)

LEF1

Cytology description

* Numerous polyhedral epithelial cells and occasional columnar cells with calcification and Congo red negative extracellular homogenous material in background ([Acta Cytol 2009;53:460](19697738))

Positive stains

* [β catenin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsbetacatenin.html) ([microscopic image #5](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html#mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenicmicro)) ([Hum Pathol 2015;46:255](25497834), [APMIS 2008;116:206](18377586), [Pathol Int 2006;56:732](17096730), [Am J Clin Pathol 2003;120:732](14608900), [Am J Pathol 2003;163:1707](14578169))* [LEF1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsLEF1.html) ([microscopic image #6](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenic.html#mandiblemaxillacalcifyingodontogenicmicro)) ([Hum Pathol 2015;46:255](25497834))* Cytokeratins [7](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck7.html), [8](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck8.html), [14](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck14.html) and [19](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck19.html) ([J Oral Pathol Med 2003;32:163](12581386))* Amelogenesis related proteins ([J Oral Pathol Med 2012;41:272](21936873))* **MMPs** ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol Endod 2011;112:609](21903428))* Hard α [keratins](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsckgeneral.html) ([Am J Clin Pathol 2005;123:376](15716233))* [Podoplanin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsD240.html) ([J Oral Sci 2012;54:165](22790409))* [Ki67](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainski67.html) lower in COC than in other odontogenic tumors with ghost cells and solid growth pattern ([Oral Oncol 2009;45:515](18723387))

Negative stains

* Nothing useful or significant

Electron microscopy description

* Basal and suprabasilar cells contain tonofilaments and organelles* Ghost cells contain coarse bundles of tonofilaments intermingled with dilated membranous organelles ([Med Electron Microsc 2002;35:109](12181653), [Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol 1975;39:769](1056580))

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* Aberrations of Wnt signaling pathway with β catenin overexpression ([APMIS 2008;116:206](18377586))* Mutations in *CTNNB1* but not *BRAF* ([PLoS One 2017;12:e0180224](28658279))

Sample pathology report

* Anterior maxilla, right, excisional biopsy:
  + Calcifying odontogenic cyst (calcifying cystic odontogenic tumor) 1.2 cm

Differential diagnosis

* [Ameloblastoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaameloblastoma.html) **(conventional or unicystic)**:
  + Usually lacks ghost cells and calcifications* [Dentinogenic ghost cell tumor](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxilladentinogenicghost.html) / [carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaghostcellodontogeniccarcinoma.html)
    + Solid counterpart of COC* [Ghost cell odontogenic carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaghostcellodontogeniccarcinoma.html):
      + Infiltrative+ Exhibits mitotic activity, nuclear atypia or necrosis* [Odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaodontoma.html):
        + Lacks the ameloblastic epithelium of COC* [Ameloblastic fibro-odontoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/mandiblemaxillaodontoma.html):
          + Exhibits primitive mesenchymal stroma

Additional references

* [Barnes: WHO Classfication of Head and Neck Tumours, 3rd Edition, 2005](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283224175/pathologyoutl-20), [El-Naggar: WHO Classfication of Head and Neck Tumours, 4th Edition, 2017](https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/9283224388/pathologyoutl-20)
